contextId.information: Some people thought they were righteous. Jesus referred to them by the way they thought about themselves even though he knew that they were not righteous. AT: "people who think they are righteous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])

"from people who are wise and have understanding." Because God had concealed truth from them, these people were not actually wise and understanding, even though they thought they were. AT: "from people who think they are wise and educated" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

The Jewish leaders claimed to serve God. And yet their ancestors killed many of God's prophets in Jerusalem, and Jesus knew that they would kill him there too. AT: "it is in Jerusalem that the Jewish leaders kill God's messengers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
contextId.quote: it is not acceptable to kill a prophet away from Jerusalem

contextId.information: The guards did not believe that Jesus was a prophet. Rather they believed that a real prophet would know who hit him even if he could not see it. They called Jesus a prophet, but they wanted to show that he was not a prophet. AT: "Prove that you are a prophet. Tell us who hit you!" or "Hey prophet, who hit you?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
contextId.quote: Prophesy! Who is the one who hit you?

contextId.information: Luke records the ironic words of the rulers. The only way Jesus could save others was by dying instead of saving himself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
contextId.quote: He saved others. Let him save himself
